description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med FAO om bidrag till humanitära insatser 2014-2016. Beslutet tas i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel paragraf 3.11.3. och avser tillägg till tredje året av ett treårigt avtal.
Sidas humanitära enheten har tidigare lämnat stöd till FAO för enstaka projekt inom ramen för nu gällande avtal 2014-2016. Ett antal insatser är tre-åriga och avslutas nu under 2016, detta gäller insatser i Etiopien, Kenya, Tchad, Mali och Niger. Under landanalysprocessen för 2016 har FAO identifierats som en lämplig partner i ett antal humanitära kriser och nya eller förlängda insatser utöver tidigare avtalat föreslås i Somalien, Djibouti, Colombia, och Tchad. FAO har även föreslagit stöd till det globala kluster för livsmedelstrygghet och till en studie över det tre åriga samarbetet 2014-2016 i syfte att lämna bättringsförslag för ett nytt tre-årigt avtal mellan Sida/HUM och FAO för perioden 2017-2019.
Stödet 2016, uppgående till SEK 30 400 000 kommer att användas för finansiering av projekt i följande länder;
Somalia 10 MSEK, varav 5 MSEK till projektet FSNAU och 5 MSEK till Resiliens programmet Tchad 5 MSEK (5 MSEK 2014, 4 MSEK 2015, 2 MSEK 2016) varav 3 MSEK för ett nytt projekt för stöd till flyktingar från Nigeria Niger 2 MSEK (5 MSEK 2014, 5 MSEK 2015, 2 MSEK 2016) Colombia 3 MSEK (3,5 MSEK 2014, 4 MSEK 2015) Djibouti 1.7 MSEK (2 MSEK 2015) Ethiopia 2 MSEK (5 MSEK 2014, 2 MSEK 2015, 2 MSEK 2016) Kenya 2 MSEK (5 MSEK 2014, 2 MSEK 2015, 2 MSEK 2016) Mali 2 MSEK (7 MSEK 2014, 2 MSEK 2015, 2 MSEK 2016)
Dessutom föreslås stöd till den Globala Livsmedelstrygghetskluster 2.2 MSEK (1.5 MSEK 2014) och 0.5 MSEK till en studie om resultat och lärdomar av pågående avtalsperiod 2014-2016.
Stöd till den föreslagna insatsen bedöms som fortsatt relevant, insatsen har som syfte att rädda liv och lindra nöd genom humanitära insatser för att återställa den drabbade befolkningens matförsörjning och beredskap att bemöta framtida matförsörjningskriser. Erfarenheterna har varit positiva såsom framkommit av FAOs rapportering och ett flertal uppföljningsbesök genom Sida handläggare.
Projekten ligger väl inom FAOs kärnkompetens och avser att bygga upp motståndskraft hos drabbade befolkning för att bättre stå mot och återhämta sig från olika former av chock, sk resiliens. FAO har lång erfarenhet av resiliens arbete i de berörda länderna, och det är just det som är mervärdet i de föreslagna insatserna. Val av samarbetspartners och eventuell upphandling av varor och tjänster kommer att ske enligt de riktlinjer och regler som gäller inom FAO.
Vidare så bedömer Sida att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas ut omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2016. Detta för att på bästa sätt möjliggöra planering och genomförande av den humanitära insatsen utan fördröjning. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.
Support to humanitarian interventions through FAO 2014-16

FAO Strategic Objective 5 is to "Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises". The humanitarian operations are usually related to SO5 which has the following four Organisational Outcomes (OO): OO1 - countries and regions have legal, policy and institutional systems and regulatory frameworks for disaster and crisis risk management for agriculture, food and nutrition, OO2 - countries and regions deliver regular information and trigger timely actions against potential, known and emerging threats to agriculture, food, and nutrition, 003 - countries apply prevention and impact mitigation measures that reduce risks for agriculture, food and nutrition, OO4 - countries and regions affected by disasters and crises with impact on agriculture, food and nutrition are prepared for, and manage effective responses. The objectives of the intervention were as following: Niger (2014-2016): Food and nutrition security of vulnerable housholds is improved through an increase in rain-fed production Kenya (2014-2015): Improved adaptive capacity, access to productive assets and stability of vulnerable communities Chad (2014-2016): Increase cereal and vegetable production Mali (2014-2016): The ability of 1500 households to protect and rebuild their livelihoods are enhanced through vouchers for work Ethiopia (2014-2016): Improved upper watershed management

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In 2014 (and 2015 and 2016 through subsequent amendments to the initial agreement), the Government of Sweden through the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida), contributed to SEK 153.9 million to FAO’s emergency and rehabilitation programme. This funding supported the implementation of 12 emergency and rehabilitation projects. In Cameroon, Sida assistance supported 1 359 internally displaced households affected by the Boko Haram insurgency through small-scale livestock production support. The households received nearly 3 600 and goats and 2 440 local chickens, material for construction of shelters. Also, 32 field technicians were trained in animal production and disease control. FAO support in Chad comprised two projects contributing to building resilience of vulnerable households affected by the Lake Chad crisis. The first project reached 28 749 households which enabled the production of 27 600 tonnes of cereals, legumes and vegetables. Under the second Sida-funded project, 1 151 households were provided 15.1 tonnes of cereal and vegetable seed, producing nearly 3 300 tonnes of food. In Colombia, FAO supported the agriculture-based livelihoods of communities affected by violence. To initiate rapid food production, 123 community demonstrations training centers (CDCs) were established, enabling 4 255 beneficiary households, and subsequently achieving harvest of 500 kg over a period of six months. Households also gained knowledge, skills, materials and seeds for continuing their food production, which led to 56 percent of beneficiaries improving their dietary diversity scores and 60 percent reducing their monthly food purchase expenses by USD 75. In Djibouti, as a result of Sida funding, the country utilized an early warning system capable of collecting and analyzing data ranging several environmental and food access indicators. To improve the resilience of El Niño-affected pastoral communities, community-based risk reduction and management (DDR/M) was supported in rural areas. Sida support in Ethiopia improved the food security and agricultural production of 60 000 community members through enhanced management of rainwater resources and flood mitigation, as well as support to tree nurseries resulting in the planting of 120 000 trees. In Guinea, emergency assistance was critical to the revival of production among EVD-affected communities. Input and training were provided by 57 groups (fishers, fish smokers and fishmongers), benefiting 1 645 households. The project resulted in a 50 percent increase in fish caught per day, and a 20 percent increase in fish processed daily. FAO activities in Kenya helped improve livelihood resilience and food security by increasing access to productive assets and improving the management of natural resources. Management of different tools improved access rangeland resources for 2 200 households. As a result, committees saw significant reduction in natural resource-based conflicts. A total of 53 livestock producer’s groups developed and implemented business plans, resulting in a 50 percent increase in income among some beneficiaries. The Sida-funded project in Mali was building the resilience for farmers and agropastoralists affected by insecurity and climate change. About 1 500 households gained access to critical inputs. Under a cash-for-work scheme, households regenerated 10 000 ha of grazing land managed by community-level committees, boosting the incomes of 4 643 people and improving the local feed availability. In the Niger, FAO has helped to improve the food and nutrition security of 111 800 vulnerable households by strengthening their production capacity. From 2014 to 2016, nearly 90.8 million tonnes of food crops were produced as a result of inputs and training received, ensuring food availability and covered five months of the lean season. The project also pre-positioned 495 tonnes of millet seed at 11 warehouses, in order to enable vulnerable households’ quick access to productive assets in conflict-affected areas. In Sierra Leone, the Sida-funded project contributed to post-Ebola recovery efforts through improving agricultural productivity of women farmers to restore their agribusinesses. An integrated approach provided a mix of cash, loans and capacity building to women’s farmers groups. The project reached a total of 2 520 households belonging to 84 women’s groups.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
